story: Gavin and Susan Love of Love Sweets and Ices, who are already based on the busy street, plan to move into the premises vacated by the Royal Bank of Scotland .The building closed its doors at the end of May and has lain empty since.Now Love Sweets and Ices is hoping to be in the new premises ndash as well as the existing shop ndash and trading by spring next year.Mr Love said: ldquoWe have been looking for a new premises for a wee while. We are looking to be trading from March next year.Love Sweets and Ices has been trading on the opposite side of the road from the former bank for six years.However, a sweet shop on the site dates back more than  years.Mr Love said that the shop would be based in the front of the former bank, with rooms such as the managerrsquos office used for storage.Philip Mellor, chairman of the Dunbar Tradesrsquo Association , was pleased to see the building being brought back into use.He said: ldquoThe redevelopment of the old RBS bank on the High Street further demonstrates the demand for retail space in Dunbar.ldquoWe wish the new owners every success with the refurbishment of this iconic building and welcome the plans that Love Sweets and Ices has for the space.A decision to close  RBS and  NatWest branches came at the end of last year, with RBS branches in North Berwick and Dunbar shutting.The move was widely criticised by local politicians, with ward councillor Paul McLennan among those unhappy at the decision.In January, he said: ldquoThe social and community impact on the North Berwick and Dunbar communities of these branch closures will be substantial.ldquoThe RBS in Dunbar is in the centre of the town and will impact on the sustainability of High Street.

title: iain-gray-why-we-must-remember-srebrenica
story: THIS year I attended many events in East Lothian marking the end of the First World War  years ago, not least the moving drumhead service by the Moderator of the Church of Scotland in Haddington on November .The following day, I found myself standing in remembrance as anotherModerator, the Very Rev Lorna Hood, said a few words on the exact spot where that war began, rather than ended.I was in Sarajevo, Bosnia, on the street corner where in  Serb nationalist Gavrilo Princip assassinated Archduke Ferdinand, igniting the chain of events which engulfed the world in war for four long years.Our main purpose, though, was to learn about a much more recent conflict, the Balkans war of the s, on a delegation organised by the Remembering Srebrenica Scotland charity, which Lorna chairs.Just as the Second World War revealed that we had not learned from that first ldquowar to end all wars, so in  the Bosnian town of Srebrenica showed that we had not learned the lessons of the Holocaust, as genocide took place again on European soil while the world stood by and watched.Serbs, Croats and Bosnian Muslims had lived together peacefully. However, when the fall of communism led to the break-up of Yugoslavia, war came to Bosnia in , driven in part by Serbiarsquos desire to create a lsquoGreater Serbiarsquo, including large parts of Bosnia, from which they planned to remove Croats and Muslims in what became known as lsquoethnic cleansingrsquo.Our delegation leader Resad Trbonja was , living in Sarajevo. On April , , he woke to find his city under siege, surrounded by Serbian artillery and snipers on the mountains overlooking the city. The siege would last four years, the longest in modern warfare, longer than Stalingrad. An average of  mortars landed in the city every day, , on the worst day.Resad, who lived through, and fought in, the siege, explained that Sarajevo regressed two centuries overnight ndash no water, no electricity, no phones. The Serbian army allowed minimal UN aid into the city sporadically but nothing .The survival of the siege is a story of human courage, spirit and defiance.Our first visit was to the remnants of a tunnel, dug under Sarajevo airport to reach Bosnian-held territory on the other side. This tiny tunnel was the only way in or out for four years.Through this tunnel extra aid came, for example from Edinburgh Direct Aid, who drove lorries of supplies from Edinburgh to help Sarajevans. My own predecessor, John Home Robertson, then MPfor East Lothian, spent several Parliamentary recesses as a volunteer lorry driver. It was dangerous work and one of his colleagues died on the notorious road known as lsquoSnipers Alleyrsquo.Perhaps the most affecting visit in Sarajevo was to the War Childhood Museum, where those who grew up in the siege display the things they kept to remind them of what it was like, and tell their story.A homemade cardboard knightrsquos breastplate made by a brother who later died a cuddly toy from a UN delivery, cuddled threadbare because it was the only toy a homemade lsquounormrsquo for a childrenrsquos choir which rehearsed and performed in defiance of bombs and bullets the remains of a playpark lsquojungle gymrsquo kept to remember the day a mortar tore it apart and killed your friend ndash no one who visits this museum will forget it.That is true too of Srebrenica. This was supposedly a lsquosafe havenrsquo protected by UN troops. Yet on July , Serbian paramilitary units overran it. Thousands of Bosnian Muslims sought refuge in the UN base at a disused factory.When we visited the museum now sited there, survivor Hasan Hasanovic explained to us how UN soldiers stood by as women and children were herded onto buses and deported, while their men were separated and removed in lorries. They were systematically murdered nearby. Thousands more who tried to escape through the forest were hunted down, shepherded into a meadow, and shot. In all, , Bosnian Muslim men and boys were slaughtered at Srebrenica.Finally, the international community acted. In a matter of days, air strikes lted the siege of Sarajevo, drove Serbian paramilitaries out of much of the territory they had occupied, and forced agreement to a peace deal signed in Dayton, Ohio.Srebrenica was not the only genocide in this war, but it is emblematic because it happened under the noses of the UN and because of the bravery of the Mothers of Srebrenica, who ed home to find out what happened to their husbands and sons, refused to be silenced, and demanded justice.This led to the International Commission on Missing Persons and the forensic anthropology unit in Tuzla, where we saw the incredible work done to identy remains using DNA. More than , victims of genocide have now been identied, allowing their families to grieve and to bury them at the final stop of our visit.We arrive at the cemetery at Potaceri, outside Srebrenica, as the sun sets. On the hillside, , stark white tombstones bring home the enormity of what was done over only a few days a mere  years or so ago.More than , died at Srebrenica , perished in Sarajevo , women suffered rape as an act of war millions fled their homes, some even finding their way to the refugee reception centre at Cheylesmore Lodge in North Berwick.All the survivors I met asked the same question: why did so much suffering have to happen before the international community acted to stop it  In telling us their story, they relived their own pain. They did so in the hope that we learn the lessons of Bosnia. We need only look at Syria or Yemen to know that we have not.That is why we must remember Srebrenica.If any local groups would like to hear more about the work of Remembering Srebrenica, please contact my office on  .

title: msps-vote-to-reject-brexit-withdrawal-plans-and-no-deal-scenario
story: MSPs voted by  to  for a motion which said both these options ldquowould be damaging for Scotland and the nations and regions of the UK as a whole.As a result they called for the Brexit deal to be rejected when it is voted on at Westminster on December  and for ldquoa better alternative be taken forward.The motion which was passed had been drawn up by the SNP, Labour, the Scottish Greens and the Liberal Democrats ndash with Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell describing it as a ldquounique collaboration.Pleased the Scottish Parliament has rejected Mayrsquos deal and No deal by -mdash Neil Findlay MSPDecember , After it was overwhelmingly passed Mr Russell said: ldquoThe Scottish Parliament came together to say we cannot let this happen, and the UK Government must now respect todayrsquos decisive vote.ldquoThe UK Governmentrsquos Brexit deal will make Scotland poorer and they must now listen and act on the Scottish Parliamentrsquos overwhelming decision to reject it.Only Conservative MSPs at Holyrood voted against the motion, with SNP MSP Bruce Crawford, convener of the Parliamentrsquos Constitution Committee, saying afterwards the cross-party stance by MSPs demanded a new approach from the PM.Mr Crawford added: ldquoWith the Scottish Parliament now overwhelmingly against the  choice of Theresa Mayrsquos deal or no deal, it is time for the UK government to listen.ldquoTheresa Mayrsquos deal is at this point little more than a hypothetical exercise, with all sides of the House of Commons determined to defeat it on Tuesday.ldquoThe clock is ticking. Itrsquos time for a new approach and to look at the real alternatives ndash whether that be a second referendum giving Scotland the opportunity to remain in the EU, or the compromise proposal of staying in the single market that the Scottish Government unveiled two years ago.BREAKING: The Scottish Parliament has voted overwhelmingly to reject the Tories terrible deal and the calamity of a No Deal, agreeing a joint SNP Labour Green Lib Dem motion #Brexit pic zziPXpcmdash Ross GreerDecember , During the debate Mr Russell had argued Mrs Mayrsquosdraft withdrawal agreement was ldquoabout saving the Prime Minister, not about saving her country.And he warned it wouldprolong the UKrsquos Brexit ldquouncertainty ndash saying this could last until December the transition period has to be extended.He warned: ldquoThatrsquos at least four years of uncertainty to add to the two-and-a-half wersquove already had.ldquoFour more years of stagnation and lack of investment, with no guarantee that a free trade deal will ever be struck. Those are the fruits of Conservative government. More of the same and worse.ldquoMore meaningless assertions,  claims, clf-edge negotiations and economic lack of confidence and security. It mustnrsquot happen. Scotland needs and deserves better than the Prime Ministerrsquos blindfold Brexit.The PMs Brexit deal honours the vote of , and means we can leave the EU in an orderly manner without sparking the chaos and misery a no-deal would likely bring. pic MnsParrhxmdash ScotConservativesDecember , Labour Brexit spokesman Neil Findlay said: ldquoMSPs have come together to show their contempt for Theresa Mayrsquos botched Brexit deal.ldquoThe Tories need to realise their plan is bad for Scotland and the rest the UK, bad for jobs and industries and bad for our communities.But Scottish Conservatives said: ldquoThe PMrsquos Brexit deal honours the vote of , and means we can leave the EU in an orderly manner without sparking the chaos and misery a no-deal would likely bring.The Toriesrsquo constitution spokesman Adam Tomkins had argued: ldquoEither we leave the EU on the basis of the orderly Withdrawal Agreement that the Prime Minister and her team have negotiated, or something very close to it, or we crash out of the EU on a no-deal basis that would be a disaster for the economy.Hestressed Brexit is happening because the UK as a wholevoted to leave the EU in , adding: ldquoIf it turns out that we, the Scottish Conservatives, are alone in standing up for the one million Scots who voted for that outcome, so be it.

title: waymo-launches-trial-ride-hailing-service-with-self-driving-car
story: Waymo is introducing a small-scale ride-hailing service in the Phoenix area that will include a human behind the wheel in case the robotic vehicles mal.The service marks a signicant milestone for Waymo, a company that began as a secretive project within Google in .Since then, its cars have robotically logged more than  million miles on public roads in  cities in Calornia, Arizona, Washington, Michigan and Georgia while getting into only a few accidents mdash mostly minor.Today, were taking the next step in our journey with the introduction of our commercial self-driving service, Waymo One. #everystep https:t.co SgawRVfM pic kRZtAgRdamdash WaymoDecember , The company is initially operating the new service cautiously, underscoring the challenges still facing its autonomous vehicles as they navigate around vehicles with human drivers that do not always follow the same rules as robots.The service, dubbed Waymo One, at first will only be available to a couple of hundred riders, all of whom had already been participating in a free pilot programme that began in April .It will be confined to a roughly -square-mile area in and around Phoenix, including the neighbouring cities of Chandler, Tempe, Mesa and Gilbert.Although Waymo has been driving passengers without humans behind the wheel in its free pilot programme, it decided to be less daring with the new commercial service.ldquoSelf-driving technology is new to many, so wersquore proceeding carefully with the comfort and convenience of our riders in mind, Waymo chief executive John Krafcik wrote a blog post heralding the new service.The ride-hailing service is launching in the same area where a car using robotic technology from Uber hit and killed a pedestrian crossing a darkened street in Tempe, Arizona, seven months ago.That collision attracted worldwide attention that cast a pall over the self-driving car industry as more people began to publicly question the safety of the vehicles.The Uber robotic car had a human safety driver behind the wheel, but that was not enough to prevent the accident in March.

title: theyre-acting-like-scrooge-scotrail-to-end-free-rail-travel-for-children
story: The popular lsquoKids Go Freersquo scheme, which enables an adult to take up to two children for free onjourneys, will end in the New Year as part of a rail fare rise.Each child will be charged pound from next year, meaning an adult who travels once a week with two children will be more than pound worse-off after the scheme is cancelled.Scottish Labour slammed the move, calling the fare rise a ldquorip-off.The partyrsquos transport spokesman, Colin Smyth MSP, said: ldquoWith Christmas less than a few weeks away, itrsquos sad to see bosses at ScotRail acting like Scrooge by taking free rail travel away from children across Scotland.ldquoThe Kids Go Free scheme is a fantastic initiative which encourages families to use public transport and not be out of pocket for doing so.ldquoThis rip-off fare rise will see passengers handing out even more money to a private company which is failing them time and time again.ldquoI hope ScotRail see sense and give our children the gt of free rail travel for another year this Christmas.According to the Daily Record, ScotRail said: ldquoWe are committed to providing our customers with the opportunity to travel across our services and the Kids for a Quid offer is available on a wider range of adult tickets.

title: when-is-the-irn-bru-carnival-coming-to-glasgow-and-how-much-are-tickets
story: With over  rides and attractions under one roof, the Irn-Bru Carnival will see thrilling rides with new additions Airmaxx  and the Wild Mouse Rollercoaster guaranteed to excite even the biggest daredevils.Family favourites, the sticky wall and carousel will also be ing for another year.There will also be over  classic game stalls and activities, including classic arcade games, basketball, whac-a-minion and an inflatable paradise.Greg Cherry, managing director of QD Events, organisers of the event, said: ldquoAs we celebrate our th birthday next year, itrsquos apparent that the Irn-Bru Carnival has become an iconic part of Scotlandrsquos festive season.ldquoNot only have we entertained generations of families and friends, but wersquove continued to grow year-on-year with new thrilling experiences to be enjoyed by both ing and new guests.The carnival s on Thursday, December  and will be open until Sunday, January .Advance tickets are available now from pound for general admission and pound for concessions.All general admission tickets will include entry as well as  ride vouchers per person.For more information, visit irn-bru-carnival.

title: scots-takeaway-selling-monster-deep-fried-christmas-dinner-munchy-box
story: James Ellinsworth, , has only been selling the ,-calorie feast for three days but it has already proved so popular that he sold out of turkey legs.The monster crunchy box includes roast potatoes, pigs-in-blankets, carrots, and sprouts - all battered and dipped in hot oil.The festive feast will be on sale at Aprilrsquos Plaice, Buckhaven, Fe, until Christmas Eve, costing pound.Dad-of-one James, originally from Blackpool, Lancs, is offering diners two options for the deep-fried poultry - either chicken, or turkey.James said: ldquoThe Scots will batter anything.ldquoI have had people that have walked in here and have walked into my shop and askedI will batter a Bounty, or even a pickled egg.ldquoWe do a deep fried chicken supper.ldquoWe are giving people the option of turkey or chicken, and Irsquove found people tend to prefer chicken.ldquoBut we sold out of turkey at the weekend.ldquoPeople end up overindulging in turkey over Christmas.The only things served up in the Christmas dinner box which are not deep fried is a mince pie and a portion of gravy.James added: ldquoI tried deep frying the mince pie but it didnrsquot go very well.ldquoThere is gravy on the side.ldquoI didnrsquot think it would take off the way it has.Even customers who object to sprouts have had their minds changed after tucking into the mega meal.James said: ldquoFor people who werenrsquot sure, I made the sprouts first and let them try them.ldquoOne guy just wanted a portion of sprouts to take home to his we.ldquoEveryone who has come in has specically ordered it, apart from one person who said lsquoI just want to try something dferentrsquo.Over the weekend, James sold ten portions of turkey and  of chicken.ldquoAt the weekend it was just mental, James said.ldquoIf it carries on like this I will absolutely do it next year.But despite the popularity of the festive feast, his daughter April, aged five, has not yet tried it and James has said he wont be eating a deep fried Christmas dinner.He added: ldquoI will be having a traditional Christmas dinner.ldquoTherersquos no way Irsquoll be having a deep fried one.

title: aberdeen-fan-admits-running-onto-hampden-pitch-and-kicking-ball-during-celtic-cup-final
story: Gavin Elpinstone vaulted the stand and made his way onto the field where he intercepted a pass from Celtic keeper Scott Bain to a teammate.The -year-old, from Aberdeen, made it past stewards but was removed from the pitch during the Hoopsrsquo - win over the Dons.Elphinstone appeared from custody at Glasgow Sherf Court where he was represented by solicitor Lee Doyle.He admitted breaching the peace on December  by conducting himself in a disorderly manner, entering the field of play and waving a scarf above his head, running towards a player and kicking the ball.He also pleaded guilty to assaulting two police officers by pushing and kicking one on the body and kicking another on the body.Sherf Ian Miller deferred sentence until later this month and remanded Elphinstone in custody.Both sets of fans accused each other of throwing flares at each other at Hampden.Some Celtic fans have also alleged that pyros were thrown from the Aberdeen end towards stewards and police.

title: ten-of-the-most-unique-scottish-food-brands
story: For those hoping to shop local and support Scottish producers, there are a wealth to choose from using only the finest ingredients.From chocolate toconfectionery, fish to cheese, there are an array of producers throughoutthe country to pick from.Discover tenScottish producers who are admired year-round for their commitment to quality and great flavour.----------------------------------Bells Food GroupBells Food Group has been part of the Scottish food landscape since  when an enterprising local baker began working from home, selling a few tasty treats in his local town. Almost  years later, Bells remains a family business with the third generation in key roles.As Scotlandrsquos leading fresh pie brand and the number four most recognised Scottish food brand in the country*, Bells employs over  people in the town where the company was born. The product range has grown over the years to include pies, savouries, cakes and pastry. All are made with care and attention, to give customers the great taste of Bells.The Bell family have always been innovators. In the early days, when the company was known as David Bell  Sons, the now famous puff pastry first made its appearance when the family saw a market for a convenient ready-made puff pastry. Then, as now, home bakers have come to rely on the quality and consistency of Bells Special Puff Pastry. Bells light, golden, flaky pastry is ideal for making your favourite steak pie or something special.And letrsquos not forget the iconic Bells Steak Pie which came in to being following a flash of inspiration whilst its creator Donald Bell was on holiday. The perfect marriage between the traditional stewing steak and delicious puff pastry, it was an instant hit. This innovative approach continues today with the addition of a Premium Aberdeen Angus Steak Pie. Hand finished with a parmesan infused, butter enriched puff pastry top crust, sprinkled with cracked black pepper, it is a crowd pleaser in every sense. This product is unique to the steak pie category and has been hugely successful in attracting new consumers to the brand. Look out for the Premium Aberdeen Angus Steak Pie at Hogmanay week, when it will be available through supermarkets across Scotland.*sources Kantar and Scottish GrocerFor more information about Bells products, visit www.bellsfoodgroup----------------------------------Bonello ChocolatierBonello Chocolatier - For Lovers of Indulgent Adventures was founded in  by award-winning artisan chocolatier, Paulene Bonello. Her lovingly handmade chocolates are specially crafted at the foot of the Ochil Hills in Tillicoultry, Scotland. She uses the best of local, Scottish and UK ingredients to create unique, hand-crafted, delicious works of chocolate art.Paulene believes in being as socially and environmentally responsible as possible, so only use chocolate that is certied by FLO-CERT, the independent international Fairtrade certication body, to produce a range of Fairtrade cocoa and artisan chocolates.This couverture is hand-tempered, hand coloured and hand cast, resulting in pretty chocolates and caramels filled with fresh, often local flavours. Paulene uses hand-grown herbs and soft fruitsto infuse into the ganache such as rosemary and olive oil, tarragon and mustard, thyme and heather honey, blackcurrant pacircte de fruit and juniper.Bonello Chocolatier specialise in Weddings, Corporate and Events.Paulene understands that when it comes to weddings and events, everything must be just perfect. She also believes in making chocolate of the highest quality, so knows that choosing her chocolates to serve at weddings or celebrations as a special boxed or bagged gt to your guests as a favour is easily achieved when working with Bonello Chocolatier.They are always happy to personalise your chocolates according to your theme, style, colour and flavour and can even add your names, monogram, wedding date or bridal quote to their delicious chocolate creations to make your special day even more memorable.Let them help you impress your corporate clients or treat your staff with a gt of chocolates adorned with your business name, logo or slogan.Find out more atwww.bonellochocolatieror follow them on Facebook.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Charles MacleodCharles Macleod Ltd is a family business that stretches back over seven decades, established by Charles Macleod in .It is now run by the third generation, his granddaughters Shona Macleod, Ria MacDonald and Rona MacDonald.A traditional crofting kitchen staple, our award winning black, white and fruit puddings are cooked daily on the premises and shipped to customers across the UK. Multi award winning, including six Great Taste Awards from the Guild of Fine Foods, our Stornoway Black Pudding is made with Scottish oatmeal to give a unique texture and the moist deep flavour is a result of high quality ingredients and fine balance of seasoning.Essential in a traditional breakfast or perfect accompaniment to a range of savoury ingredients such as scallops, chicken, beef and pork.Black puddings arrived in Britain with the ious wave of invaders, which perhaps accounts for the iation between regions. Stornoway Black Pudding is unique in that it uses only the following ingredients in order of quantity beef suet, oatmeal, onion, blood, salt and pepper with the addition of water. They are free from articial colours, flavours, bulking agents and preservatives.Unlike other regional black puddings, beef suet is a major constituent of Stornoway black puddings. In cold climates, such as the Hebrides, the high caloric value of suet makes it an ideal food in winter. The type of oatmeal grown in Scotland provides a good rough texture for the Stornoway black pudding.Stornoway Black Pudding is intrinsically linked to the arearsquos tourism, frequently purchased by visitors as a souvenir or lsquotaste of the islandsrsquo. There is world recognition of the brand and the link back to Stornoway as an area. There is also a strong diaspora of the population from the Western Isles that regularly holiday in the islands, known as ldquocoming home. This group of ex-pats are large consumers of the Stornoway ldquoMarag Dubh, always visiting their Stornoway butcher to procure several black puddings before ing ldquoto the mainland and distribute the puddings as gts to their network of colleagues and friends.Visitwww.charlesmacleodor follow them on Facebook.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Gardiners of ScotlandWhen it comes to famous sweet manufacturers borne out of Scotland, few are more popular than Lanarkshire based Gardiners of Scotland.First established in the rsquos, Gardiners long-running family business has been manufacturing the finest range of traditional Scottish confectionery for many decades. From delicious fudge and tasty butterscotch to more exotic flavours including a range of Finest Scotch Whisky fudges, Gardiners confectionery selection has a genuine global appeal which continues to grow year on year.Gardiners also supply seasonal tins, perfect as Christmas stocking fillers, while their special thank you boxes make the perfect something to give as a gt. These include a delicious range of melt-in-the-mouth handmade Scottish fudge, which now includes flavours such as Jim Beam Handmade Fudge and Baileys Luxury Fudge.Overall Gardiners donrsquot just have a reputation for producing quality confectionery. They believe that a friendly, attentive service is of paramount importance and do everything with a personal touch, just as yoursquod expect from a family business.To find out more and order from Gardiners of Scotland extensive confectionery collection, visit www.gardiners-scotlandor follow them on Facebook.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Hamlyns of ScotlandHamlyns of Scotland is part of a family food business, owned and managed by a family with  generations of history in oat milling. Their Porridge Oats and Oatmealrsquos are % Scottish: from seed to mill to finished product. For such a quintessential Scottish product, they strongly believe this is important.The business sources their oats from a network of farmers across Scotland, many of whom have worked with alongside them for several generations.The oat mill is based at Boyndie near Banff, in the heart of Scotlandrsquos oat growing countryside. Theyrsquore proud to have one of the most modern oat processing mills in Europe, combining the latest oat milling techniques with traditional customs. Itrsquos a modern-day wind mill, thanks to the wind turbine, which was installed alongside the mill a few years ago and provides all the electricity required to operate the mill.The Hamlyns of Scotland range includes Scottish Oatmeal, Scottish Porridge Oats, Scottish Porridge Oats  Bran and Pinhead Oatmeal in a re-sealable tin. All four ieties can be used to make a delicious porridge, each with a dferent distinctive taste and texture. Or try using them to make overnight oats with your favourite yoghurt, fruit and other toppings.As a rule, when yoursquore making porridge, the finer the porridge oats or oatmeal, the shorter the cooking time required. The cooking time is reduced furtheryou choose porridge oats over oatmeal, as the oats are lightly steamed during the milling process before they are rolled.You can also make a wide iety of sweet and savoury recipes. From breakfast to healthy snacks with porridge oats and oatmeal. Yoursquoll find lots to inspire you in our online recipe library, including recipes from Nick Nairn and some of Scotlandrsquos top food bloggers.Scottish Porridge Oats and Oatmeals are available in virtually every supermarket in Scotland, butyou donrsquot have a local stockist, you can buy everything by the case from the online shop.Visit hamlynsoatsor follow them onTwitter or Facebook.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Island BakeryJoe andDawn Reade were fresh-faced and naiumlve young graduates of the University of Edinburgh when they started baking bread in a converted garage in Tobermory in . The local baker was retiring, and the islanders needed someone to keep bakinglovely fresh loaves.In  they bought shop premises on Tobermoryrsquos colourful Main Street, which became the Island Bakery Delicatessen. It was through stocking the deli with tempting speciality foods that Dawn realised that there was a gap in the market for tempting organic biscuits. Keen to make something that could travel beyond Mull, the Reades thought that biscuits seemed to be an excellent product to introduce to places beyond the islandrsquos shores.In  Island Bakery Organics was born. Initially the range had just  ieties. Quality not quantity! The first biscuit customers included Harvey Nichols andSelfridges. Within the first year the company picked up several Great Taste awards and scooped an Organic Food award.By , the biscuit side of business had overtaken the deli. Soon afterwards, plans were made to build a new bakery. The new premises were completed in June . Subsequently growth in the bakery has seen growth in product with  ieties now available including the acclaimed Island Bakery Chocolate Gingers where the biscuit cognoscenti are attracted to the generous chunk of moist stem ginger peeking out from beneath dark chocolate drapery, nestling on a subtly spiced ginger biscuit.For more information visit www.islandbakeryor follow them on Facebook or Twitter.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Isle of Mull CheeseLocated near Tobermory, Isle of Mull Cheese take great pride when it comes to producing a rich iety of finely crafted cheeses.Isle of Mull Cheese has the added benefit of being run on a small family farm on the island of Mull. The dedicated team produce raw milk cheese.The Reade family farm produces all of its own sustainable energy from wind, wood, and its own hydroelectric power plant. A heat exchange system uses the heat removed from the milk in the evening to warm it back up for the cheese in the morning.Around  people,  cows, and a few pigs work hard to make the cheese and sausages. At any one time they have around  months of work in the cheese store.The family farm makes many uniquely flavoured batches with flavours ranging from savoury to peaty to juicy with a hint of citrus zest.A hearty, full-flavoured Scottish Cheddar, Isle of Mull is drier in texture than many Cheddars with flavours that are upfront, richly savoury and boozy.Isle of Mull Cheese make a range of batches including their ldquoIsle of Mull a cheddar type, and ldquoHebridean Blue a semi hard blue.The Traditional Isle of Mull Cheese was the Gold Medal winner at the World Cheese awards , and their Hebridean Blue Cheese won the Silver Medal the same year.Find out more atwww.isleofmullcheeseor view their video here.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Salar SmokehouseAnchored proudly off the West coast of Scotland and part of the Hebridean Archipelago, the Isle of South Uist is home to Salar Smokehouse.Hidden amongst the gems of the beautul Eastern shore, the Smokehouse is perfectly placed in the scenic and historical bays of Lochcarnan. This is still one of the most special, unspoilt locations in the world, where Gaelic, culture and community are still prominent in everyday le.Daily, Salar Smokehouse is surrounded by an abundance of wildle and fantastic, unrivalled scenery and most importantly The Hebridean welcome for all.First established as a small business in , the original owner designed and built his own special kilns and developed a unique process. years later the Smokehouse celebrates itsto its core values with a back to basics approach, where heritage, tradition and quality are at the core of this family run, Hebridean business, now established as a globally respected brand.The Smokehouse only source superior quality Scottish Farmed Salmon from the most reputable suppliers. Produced and packed within  hours of receipt of deliveries, ensures the freshest and most superior product for our customers.The lightly cured salmon fillets are roasted over oak smoke to produce the dark outer glaze, distinctive taste and succulent, flaky texture.Salar Smokehousersquos quality products have received recognition as they came out on top at the recent Highlands  Islands Food  Drink Awards  taking home the New Business Award and the Young Shining Star award for Donald MacLachlan.Find out more atwww.salarsmokehouse.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Stag BakeriesBased on the scenic and unspoilt island of Lewis in the Outer Hebrides, Stag Bakeries is a family-run craft bakery with a heritage going back to . Stag has been owned by Charles Macdonald for over  years and his core values remain at the heart of the business. Traditional recipes passed down the generations, time-honoured methods and a commitment to using only the finest ingredients are still key to each product that the bakery sends out from its premises in Stornoway, and the result is an award-winning product range with trusted provenance.Stag Bakeries still supplies its loyal customers on the island with bread, rolls, savouries and wide array of other daily goods, but the bakeryrsquos speciality is savoury biscuits and their signature product is their classic Stornoway Water Biscuit. Now available in two sizes and a iety of flavours, the Water Biscuit has been designed with cheeseboards in mind and is a worthy accompaniment for any kind of cheese, meat, fish or pacircteacute.In , Stag Bakeries launched the Seaweed Water Biscuits, a product inspired by the bakeryrsquos island location and the imagination of their team of bakers. In the same year, the Seaweed Water Biscuits were awarded three Gold Stars in the Great Taste awards along with the honour of winning the lsquoNigel Barden Heritage Awardrsquo and being named lsquoBest Scottish Speciality Productrsquo by the Guild of Fine Food.The Seaweed Water Biscuits are made with a blend of three seaweeds and offer a truly distinct flavour. Equally moreish on their own or paired when with any kind of topping, from stilton and fig to cheddar and pear to smoked salmon, the Seaweed Water Biscuits will liven up any cheeseboard.Visitstagbakeries.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Orkney RoasteryCoffee roasted in small batches with love and care. Giving every bean its chance to shine.At the Orkney Roastery the aim is to undertake a continuous quest to release the natural excellence of flavour in every coffee bean they roast. Join them in Ariarsquos journey all around the globe to explore and source the highest quality beans.Euan has built up a wealth of experience working at other roasteries in Scotland and then spending the last  years running a supply and service business to the catering and domestic sectors in Orkney. For the last  years it has been his ambition to roast his own coffee.The skilled team promise to keep things small and hands-on at the Orkney Roastery. Roast batches are small but frequent enough to ensure that our customers get to experience the fabulous fresh roast taste.Roasting profiles will be continuously tweaked as Orkney Roastery always pay great attention to detail at every stage. Getting the most from every bean they roast will ensure that customers have the best possible ndash and fresh- taste experience in their daily coffee lsquofixrsquo.Sara and Euan have worked together for  years and worked on a business plan for the Orkney Roastery during that time. For a iety of reasons,  was the right time to realise their ambition. The roaster was ordered and whilst building and conversion was underway, they were roasting, cupping and tasting hundreds of sample coffees and blends.One of their key targets was to create a range of exciting espressos. After many failed attempts the breakthrough finally came on Saras birthday and was nicknamed Birthday Blend before becoming Overture - the first ever Aria Coffee. The Aria range is developing all the time but following the same philosophy of getting the most out of every bean.Visitwww.theorkneyroastery.

title: scotlands-15-best-cosy-coffee-shops
story: . Steampunk Coffee Rollers, North BerwickThe Warehouse, a Kirk Ports, North BerwickMonday- Saturday am-pm, Sunday am- pm  www.steampunkcoffeeIt might be set in a former warehouse and situated over two floors, but Steampunk rollers has a surprisingly homely atmosphere, with tasteful lighting and antiqued furniture making it the type of place you could easily lose a few hours in. The coffee is artisan but the venue is completely welcoming , andyou want to create their coffee at home then they also sell their own freshly roasted beans along with a selection of brew equipment and Steampunk branded items.. Fortitude Coffee, EdinburghC York Place, EdinburghOpen Monday- Friday, am-pm, Saturday am-pm, Sunday am-pm  www.fortitudecoffeeIt might be right in the centre of Edinburgh, but Fortitude coffee offers a very dferent experience from the nearby chains and coffee franchises. The baristas have real passion and expertise, offering a huge array of drinks that include a particularly good pour over coffee and green tea. The cafeacute is cosy, with only a handful of tables, but the struggle to find a seat makes it that much sweeter when you do.. ReadingLasses, Wigtown South Main Street, Wigtown, Dumfries and GallowayOpen Monday-Saturday, am-pmand Sunday, pm-pm Nothing quite improves a trip to a coffee shop like curling up and enjoying a good book alongside your drink. Wigtown, officially designated as Scotlandrsquos National Book Town in , has no shortage of great booksellers, and ReadingLasses has an array of books lining its walls that help to create a great ambience. And, despite the name, itrsquos not just for girls.. The Steamie Coffee Roasters, Glasgow Argyle Street, Finnieston, GlasgowOpen Monday-Friday, am-pm, Saturday am-pm and Sunday am-pm www.thesteamieIn days past the local steamie would have been known for its hubbub and chatter- and this west end coffee outfit tries to make sure that its lsquoSteamiersquo offers something similar. The wood led walls make for a cosy interior while the coffee is of an excellent standard, with the beans roasted in a traditional drum roaster at The Steamiersquos own dedicated site in Glasgow.. Coffee on Wooer, Falkirk- Wooer Street, FalkirkOpen Monday-Thursday, .am- pm, Friday and Saturday .am- .pm, and Sunday am-pm Getting the seal of approval from the Scottish Independent Coffee Guide, this tucked-away Falkirk cafeacute offers great service and even better coffee. The deacutecor is quite hipster, but the welcome is warm and unassuming and there is a selection of tasty cakes to enjoy alongside your drink.. Henryrsquos Coffee House, Dundee- Seagate, DundeeOpen Monday-Saturday, am-pm, and Sunday, am-pm www.henryscoffeehouseA bit of an institution among Dundonians, Henryrsquos prides itself on being % independent. Its floor to ceiling windows offer a great vantage point to watch the world go by, but it is surprisingly cosy inside and is consistently busy with locals and tourists alike. Another bonus is that Henryrsquos has no external steps to navigate, so it is perfect for the elderly, the disabled or those with prams.. For Fika Sake, Glasgow Keith Street, Partick, GlasgowOpen Monday, am-pm, Tuesday- Wednesday am-pm, Thursday am- pm, Friday am-pm and Saturday-Sunday, am-pmwww.forfikasakeGlasgow has a lot of coffee shops, but few of them have an atmosphere like For Fika Sake. They place music at the heart of their cafeacute, with a free piano available for anyone to play and music launches held in the evenings . There are plenty of couches where you can sit and kick back with your coffee, but the highlight of the cafeacute is the snug: a couch on a  that you can climb up on to really get away from it all.. Darnley Coffee House, Stirling Bow Street, StirlingOpen every day, am-pm Nestled inside one of the oldest buildings in Stirling, the stone arches and period windows of the Darnley Coffee House make it a fortress of warmth from the Scottish weather outside. The staff are friendly and accommodating, creating an excellent atmosphere in the cafeacute, and the coffees, teas and hot chocolate are of an impressive quality.. Palmerstonrsquos Cafeacute, Dunkeld Atholl St, DunkeldMonday- Saturday, am- .pm and Sunday, am- .pm www.palmerstons.euThis retro, tearoom-style cafeacute specialises in hot drinks, cakes and scones, with delicious jams and chutneys on the side that you can buy a jar of and take home. Palmerstonrsquos prides itself on the ethical origins of its coffee, which comes from a unique blend of fairly traded Ora beans that are freshly prepared on the premises.. The Glad Cafeacute, ShawlandsA Pollokshaws Road, Shawlands, GlasgowOpen Monday- Wednesday, am-pm, Thursday and Friday, am-pm and Saturday and Sunday am-pm  www.thegladcafeEasy to miss in the bustling hubbub of Kilmarnock Road, the Glad Cafeacute is one of the most unique venues in Glasgowrsquos southside. Doubling up as a live music venue and a bar, it also has a charming cafeacute with locally roasted Dear Green coffee. Thanks to the extensive opening hours you can enjoy your coffee date long into the evening, giving you the chance to soak up the atmosphere without the worry of being rushed out. And,you do come at night, then you might be treated to some live music as an added bonus.. Kilau Coffee, Aberdeen High Street, AberdeenOpen Monday-Friday, am-pm, and Saturday am-pm Kitted out to look a bit like someonersquos living room, a visit to Kilau is almost like popping round to a friendrsquos house for a drink. The Coffee Press, Kilmarnock Bank Place, Kilmarnock, AyrshireOpen Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday, am-pm, Thursday and Friday am-pm and Sunday, am-pm www.thecoffeepressThe Coffee Press is light, bright and comfortable but the staff donrsquot hurry you out, so you can sit for as long as you want to enjoy your drink . The Cocoa Tree Shop, Pittenweem High Street, Pittenweem, East Neuk of FeOpen every day, am-pm www.pittenweemchocolateEscaping from the bracing sea wind into the warmth of the Cocoa Tree Shop is a treat enough in itself- but add in one of their speciality hot chocolates and you might just find yourself in total bliss. Damascus Drum, Hawick Silver St, Hawick, Scottish BordersOpen Monday- Saturday, am-pmwww.damascusdrumDamascus Drum opened in , but the building that it is housed in has been around since back in . This historic interior, complete with period features, creates a particularly homely atmosphere in the cafeacute- which offers a range of warming drinks that can be enjoyed with an additional shot of caramel, vanilla or hazelnut. They support over  families a year, from all over Scotland, providinga safe and welcoming base for the duration of their stay in hospital ndash whether that is for one night, two months or even three years.It costs them pound per night to provide free accommodation for a family to stay close by their sick child.ldquoIt was a surreal six weeks being here. And you look back and think lsquowhat would I have done without this place rsquo hellip I just canrsquot imagine. - The Goodall FamilyTo support them in keeping families like the Goodallrsquos close together this Christmas, please donate via JustGiving. You can help us in any of the following ways.That is:bullVolunteer your timebullDonate to help us with day to day running costs and to support our projectsbullProvide new ideas and suggestions on how we can help people in Fe.Contact Disabilities Fetoday to #nd out more on or emailhelp@disabilitiesfe.uk.You can also visit the websitewww.disabilitiesfe.org.ukor follow them on Facebook.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Scottish Refugee CouncilWill you help refugee families this winter This year Scottish Refugee Councilrsquos Christmas Appeal is raising vital funds to support refugee families in Scotland.Every penny raised will help struggling parents and children at a time of real need.The festive period is a time for getting together with loved ones and celebrating whatrsquos important, but for many refugee families it is a time of poverty and loneliness.Their family services offer a safe space for families who have nowhere  to turn and provide holistic, specialised support so that parents can begin to build a positive future to help their children thrive.In a single day, the advisors will support families who have become homeless, help parents who have no winter clothes for their children, and assist vulnerable families who are struggling through a complex legal system.The need for theirservices is greater than ever, and theycanrsquot support struggling families without your help.A donation to the Christmas Appeal will help refugee families today.Scottish Refugee Council helps people who have fled war, terrorism and human rights abuses rebuild their lives in safety in Scotland. His confidence was at rock bottom and he had no hope left.Then he came to Venture Trust. title: theresa-may-to-publish-full-legal-advice-on-brexit-deal-after-commons-defeat
story: The Prime Minister caved in moments after MPs decided her ministers were in "contempt" of Parliament.A motion tabled by Labour, the SNP, other opposition parties and the DUP which argued ministers were in contempt due to their failure to fully publish advice given to Cabinet by Attorney General Geoffrey Cox was approved by  votes to , a majority of .It also ordered the "immediate publication" of the legal advice.Andrea Leadsom, the Commons Leader, said: "Weve tested the opinion of the House twice on this very serious subject."Weve listened carefully and in light of the expressed will of the House we will publish the final and full advice provided by the Attorney General to Cabinet but recognising the very serious constitutional issues this raises I have referred the matter to the Privileges Committee to consider the implications of the humble address."MPs had earlier rejected a Government amendment to the motion, which Labour argued sought to kick the issue into the "long grass" until after the vote on the Brexit deal, by  votes to , a majority of just four.This amendment asked for the Privileges Committee to question whether ministers were in contempt of Parliament over the issue and could have delayed any publication of the advice.

title: msps-call-for-a-better-alternative-as-they-prepare-to-reject-draft-brexit-deal
story: The Greens, Labour, LibDems and SNP will unite in a symbolic vote that rejects both Theresarsquos May deal and a No Deal, and calls for an unnamed ldquobetter alternative.:David Mundell: Nicola Sturgeon could go on post-Brexit trade missions with Theresa MayHowever the Tories will say theirs is the only party backing the UK-wide result of the EU referendum, and claim the vote is being used to promote independence.Tory MSP Adam Tomkins said: ldquoThe Scottish Conservatives will, alone, oppose the motion set out by the SNP, Labour, Lib Dems and Greens today.ldquoWe know what the SNP and Greens are trying to do with this needless debate - they want to use it to manufacture yet more grievance as part of their push for a second independence referendum.ldquoThat Labour and the Liberal Democrats have once again fallen into line with the nationalists is disappointing but hardly surprising.ldquoWillie Rennie and Richard Leonard are Nicola Sturgeonrsquos little helpers.SNP Constitutional Relations Secretary Michael Russell said the vote was a "historic opportunity" for MSPs to show united opposition to Mrs Mays deal and No Deal.He said: "The UK Governments own analysis, as well as the detailed assessment from the Scottish Government, shows why the draft Brexit deal is unacceptable - it would make us poorer while extending uncertainty."It would take Scotland out of the EU against our will, removing us from the Customs Union and the European Single Market of m people - eight times larger than the UK market alone - and place Scotland at a serious competitive disadvantage with Northern Ireland."Iwelcome the cooperation we have seen so far in the Scottish Parliament. We should now reach a consensus and oppose both the proposed draft Brexit deal and the suggestion a no deal Brexit is the only alternative.":UK Parliament has won back control, say MPs, after Theresa May suffers three Brexit defeats in Commons"The Prime Ministers Brexit deal will make Scotland poorer and deliver continued uncertainty. It will mean years of further negotiations with no guarantee that a trade deal with the EU will even be agreed."This is a historic opportunity for the Scottish Parliament to come together and formally oppose both a no deal option and the Prime Ministers damaging Brexit deal.""Scottish Government analysis of the PMs draft deal to leave the European Union indicated this could result in "loss equivalent to pound, per person in Scotland compared to EU membership by ".Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie said Holyrood was poised to reject the Prime Ministerrsquos ldquodreadful deal and the horric prospect of a no-deal exit.He said: ldquoThis is the rising tide. Every MP in Westminster needs to check their conscience before considering lending their support to a deal that will make their constituents poorer.ldquoThere is no Brexit deal that can match the settlement we have today.

title: scottish-artist-charlotte-prodger-claims-2018-turner-prize
story: Charlotte Prodger, who is also representing Scotland at next years Venice Biennale, won the pound, prize.The judges awarded the prize to Ms Prodger for her solo exhibitionBridgit   Stoneymollen Trailat Bergen Kunsthall, with film that uses footage from her smart phone.Ms Prodger, accepting the award, said she was "overwhelmed" by winning the prize.The artist, who grew up in Aberdeenshire,also noted how critical funding of her work as an artist had been.The Tate, which organises the annual prize,said: "The jury admired the painterly quality ofBRIDGITand the attention it pays to art history."The work meanders through disparate associations ranging from JD Sports and standing stones to s lesbian separatism and Jimi Hendrixrsquos sound recordist. They praised the way Prodger explores lived experience as mediated through technologies and histories."Prodger, who trained at the Glasgow School of Art,has won several awards for her work: shewas awarded the Margaret Tait Award in , was shortlisted for the Jarman Award in  and, in the same year, was awarded a Paul Hamlyn Award.Ms Prodgers show in Venice will be in a formal shipyard, and will be unveiled next May.The shortlisted artists for  were: Forensic Architecture, Naeem Mohaiemen, Ms Prodger and Luke Willis Thompson.An exhibition of the four shortlisted artists is at Tate Britain until  January.

title: david-mundell-nicola-sturgeon-could-go-on-post-brexit-trade-missions-with-theresa-may
story: The Scottish Secretaryrsquos suggestion came as the UK Government signalled a more inclusive approach to future trade deals that would involve stronger participation by the Scottish and Welsh administrations. An intergovernmental concordat, setting out the proposals, is due to be published later this week.Appearing before the Commons Scottish Affairs Committee, Mr Mundell told MPs he would welcome a move to more joint trade delegations as this would produce better value for taxpayers.It was pointed out how on some occasions UK and Scottish Government representatives had visited the same country but separately.ldquoI am very open and conducive to working together, declared Mr Mundell. ldquoThere is continued scope for closer working. Irsquom sure thatrsquos what business and industry bodies want.Later, when quizzed about the possibility of the Prime Minister and First Minister going on joint trade missions, the Scottish Secretary told The Herald: "I see no reason why that shouldnt happen. Businesses shouldnt have to choose whether they work with the UK Government or the Scottish Government. I see no impediment to that...Businesses would welcome that combined approach."George Hollingbery, the International Trade Minister, giving evidence alongside Mr Mundell, stressed that at present the UK Government ldquoengaged widely with the devolved administrations but suggested there would be more liaison going forward post Brexit, referring to the intergovernmental concordat, which, he explained, would ldquoincorporate the Scottish Government into the way the UK Government approached new trade deals.Askedthis meant Scottish Government ministers would be inside the negotiating room, Mr Hollingbery replied: ldquoThe offer we are making is a full and fair one and that will satisfy any reasonable observer that the devolved authorities are having a full part in the process of not only creating the outlines of our future trade agreements but also having a role further down the line.The SNPrsquos Pete Wishart, who chairs the committee, noted how people were waiting with ldquogreat excitement about what was about to be announced.However, the minister noted how one or two of the Scottish Governmentrsquos proposals to be involved in post Brexit free trade agreements were at the ldquofar end of the bargaining scale and that their suggestion of the need to get Edinburghrsquos consent was ldquonot on the table and will never be on the table.Mr Hollingbery later stressed: ldquoItrsquos not right, however close we want to bring the devolved administrations, to take their advice and for them to represent the interests of their particular areas and responsibilities, to allow them to have an effective veto at any stage. This is a UK competence and will remain a UK competence.

title: victory-declared-as-damaging-oil-transfer-plans-in-firth-are-sunk
story: The plans by The Port of Cromarty Firth Authority involved moving up to , tonnes of oil, four times a month, between ships in the inner Moray Firth which is home to Scotlandrsquos largest population of bottlenose dolphins.But it has announced in its latest newsletter that ldquodue to higher priority projects the Port will not be pursuing the re-submission of our ship to ship at anchor application.The three-year campaign brought together the population of just over  residents with environmental campaigners, politicians and even celebrities such as author Ian Rankin, to an online petition which gained more than , signatures.Kate Forbes, the constituency MSP for the Black Isle, who has campaigned against the plans by Port of Cromarty Firth, said that: ldquoThe most remote communities in Scotland have great weight.Speaking to The Herald, she said: ldquoThis has been a huge sigh of relief because there was a lot of heavy campaigning at the beginning, with a petition endorsed by big names and a debate at the Scottish Parliament which I spoke in.ldquoFrom the beginning, the protesters from a tiny little village right on the periphery of the Black Isle, managed to get the support of some of the biggest environmental lobby groups, as well as the First Minister. They really went global and this will be a huge relief for them.The Cromarty Rising group, who led the protests and petition, gave a message of gratitude to all those who had supported the campaign: ldquoThanks to all who gave their support in a hard fought campaign. It is not an admission of defeat by the Port but the nearest we will ever see in print.ldquoFor whatever reason, itrsquos great for the communities and environment of the Inner Moray Firth that this project has finally be dropped and testament to the what people can do when we get together for a common cause. In the meantime, Cromarty Rising will remain vigilant to ensure this proposal is never resurrected.The plans were described by the Professor Paul Thompson, a leading expert in marine le at the University of Aberdeen, as: ldquoThe least appropriate location on the whole coast of Europe to undertake this activity.Despite this, the proposal was submitted to the Marine Coastguard Authority, based in England, which Scottish politicians have no power over since it is not devolved.Ms Forbes said this was ldquosuch a clear illustration of the dficulties of having some powers devolved and some powers reserved.Bottlenose dolphins, of which only several hundred live in British waters, are protected, with the Moray Firth being a conservation area under EU law.A spokesperson for Scottish Natural Heritage said: ldquoThis decision will signicantly reduce the risks to the worldrsquos most northerly population of bottlenose dolphins.ldquoThe Moray Firth Special Area of Conservation is extremely important to this species, and a large proportion of the local population use these waters all year. Even small oil spills could have a harmful effect.Drew Hendry, MP for Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey, said: ldquoThis is fantastic news. I vehemently opposed this application, as did % of the residents of Nairn who responded to my community survey. This is a victory for all the local campaigners who fought so hard to ensure ship to ship didnrsquot happen here.

title: aberdeen-university-lowers-poor-student-target
story: But now it has emerged that one of Scotlandrsquos oldest universities has been allowed to drop the  per cent recruitment target for young people from the poorest postcodes as its main recruitment area in the north-east is too wealthy.The Scottish Funding Council has set the University of Aberdeen a target of % for recruitment from the % of poorer areas by , below that agreed with other institutions.In recent years the university has recruited only between % and % of students from the % of poorer postcodes areas, referred to as the Scottish Index of Multiple Deprivation ndash largely due to the very low proportion classied as such in its traditional recruitment area.The Scottish Government wants one in five university students to come from the poorest areas by .Currently, only the University of the West of Scotland and Glasgow Caledonian University have reached this target, while Edinburgh University said % of its new undergraduate students this year were from the most deprived parts of Scotland.To help increase this figure, Edinburgh announced it will use this yearrsquos clearing process to award places to those from deprived areas.The most recent national statistics which are available show that in  , .% of Scottish university students came from SIMD areas.Watchdogs want universities to pay less attention to exam results and more to the candidatersquos own experience and potential ndash so-called ldquocontextualised admissions.This is in response to the view that it is easier for children from affluent backgrounds to get the passes required for some courses because of parental help, private tuition or the culture at particular schools.However, there has been criticism of using SIMD areas as a standard, with Universities Scotland ndash the body which represents all  of Scotlandrsquos educational institutions ndash saying its was an ldquoinadequate guide when determining whether a student came from a deprived background.Earlier this year, Dr Elisabet Weedon, deputy director of the Centre for Research in Education, Inclusion and Diversity at the University of Edinburgh, said that relying on SIMD data posed regional problems and could result in disabled students and care-experienced students being excluded.Writing in Holyrood magazine, she said: ldquoTherersquos a danger that you forget that there are dferent types of impairments and dferent social backgrounds of those students. I think thatrsquos a big challenge, that we need to look more deeply at the dferences between students.Despite facing a lower benchmark for participation from students of less well-off backgrounds, University of Aberdeen has pledged to meet the % target by next year.University bosses plan to introduce a number of measures to help it surpass the % target two years ahead of schedule, including a plan to provide more places for students from widening access backgrounds.The university will also accept applications from SIMD students after the UCAS deadline of January .Funding will be made available to assist applicants and offer-holders with travel costs to the universityrsquos recruitment activities and events, such as Open Day or Articulation Day.The university will continue to offer free accommodation for the first year of study for students from SIMD areas.University Principal George Boyne said: ldquoThis university was founded on the guiding principle of being open to all, and it is for this reason that we have set this ambitious new target to recruit % of our Scottish students from SIMD areas, from September .ldquoOur commitment to widening access to higher education has resulted in a number of initiatives to open up pathways to university for students from disadvantaged backgrounds, however, we undoubtedly face unique challenges here in the north-east, which I was pleased to discuss with the minister during todayrsquos visit. Despite these challenges, our new target provides a renewed impetus to our widening access activities, which I consider to be a priority area for the university.ldquoAlong with the introduction of several new measures ndash including our plan to promote more opportunities for students from SIMD backgrounds through clearing this is a signicant step in our journey towards greater inclusion.Richard Lochhead, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Minister for Further Education, took part in a discussion with Mr Boyne yesterday which covered the challenges faced by the university in attracting students from widening access backgrounds.Mr Lochhead, said: ldquoI welcome the University of Aberdeenrsquos commitment to recruit more students from disadvantaged backgrounds to this impressive institution. The Scottish Government wants every young person in Scotland to have an equal chance of success, no matter their background or circumstance. It is our aim that, by , % of students entering university will be from Scotlandrsquos most deprived backgrounds.ldquoWidening access initiatives, such as the work announced by the University of Aberdeen today, provide the opportunity for young people to fulfil their potential at university.

title: the-uks-venerable-literary-prize-prepares-for-100-year-birthday-in-edinburgh
story: Now the judging for one of the UKs longest running literary prizes has begun in the capital.The annual judging round of the James Tait Black Prizes, which has honoured writers as acclaimed as Graham Green, DH Lawrence, Muriel Spark and Ian McEwan in its long history, has begin with the arrival of  eligible books at the University of Edinburgh.The prizes have been presented by the University since  and have a distinguished lineage: four winners of the Nobel Prize in Literature have been awarded a James Tait Black Prize earlier in their career.Yesterday postgraduate students June Laurenson and Vivek Santayana launched the judging process and distributed books to  student readers who will assess each entry.Each year, books are considered by staff in English Literature at the university, assisted by a reading  of postgraduate students.Last year, the fiction award was won by Eley Williams for Attrib. and other Stories, while the biography award was won by Craig Browns Maam Darling.Each category in the awards has a cash prize of pound,: a shortlist of eight books ndash four in each category ndash will be announced in the spring of next year.The winners ndash announced in August ndash will join an illustrious list of past writers honoured by the award.DH Lawrence won in  for The Lost Girl, and EM Forster for A Passage to India in , Greenes The Heart of the Matter won in  and Spark won in  for The Mandelbaum Gate.Winners in the s included John Banville, William Golding and Iris Murdoch, while the s saw prizes for James Kelman, Salman Rushdie, JM Coetzee, JG Ballard and George Mackay Brown.More recent winners include Zadie Smiths White Teeth in , Andrew OHagan for Personality in , David Peaces GB in , and Eimer McBride for The Lesser Bohemains in .Distinguished names appear on the list of biography winners.Among them are Peter Ackroyd, Martin Amis, Quentin Bell, John Buchan, Richard Ellmann, Kathryn Hughes and Hermione Lee.Dr Alex Lawrie, fiction judge for the prize, said: "We are very much looking forward to preparing the shortlist this year."This centenary year is a fantastic opportunity to celebrate the rich history of the James Tait Black Prizes, and the wonderful contribution they make to honouring great literature."Last year, he said of Ms Williams book: "A remarkable set of short stories: experimental in the best way possible, articulating moments of intense intimacy with stunning freshness and clarity."The awards were founded by Janet Coats, the widow of publisher James Tait Black, of AC Black, to commemorate her husbandrsquos "love of good books."Only the Hawthornden Prize, in the UK, has been running as long.The first fiction winner was Hugh Walpole for The Secret City, a work about the Russian Revolution.Henry Festing Jones won the inaugural biography prize for his book about the writer and artist Samuel Butler.The lead student reader for the Biography prize, June Laurenson, said: ldquoOur  of readers come from a wide-range of specialist backgrounds."They have the critical, analytical, and creative skills to enable them to identy potential prize-winners."We are looking forward to spending the coming weeks sting through the entries to find the books that balance academic merit with being and engaging reads."Vivek Santayana, a student reader for the fiction prize, said: ldquoAs the new entries arrive, there is a sense of excitement and anticipation among the readers."We all look forward to discovering fresh stories and helping to contribute to the next chapter of the history of the prizes."In , the awards were extended to include a new category for drama, and in  an online course was also launched.

title: irvine-welshs-former-housing-estate-muirhouse-to-get-book-festival
story: The Trainspotting authors childhood stomping ground will also get its own writer-in-residence under a three-year-project aimed at engaging people with culture.Mr Welsh has spoken of how he got a criminal record aged just eight years old after a kickaround outside a block of flats in Muirhouse led to a court appearance - which he described as ldquoeducative and exciting.And a neighbouring family, the Begbies, who lived in the scheme, were the inspiration for the name of one of his most famous characters.The estate was built in the s, and organisers of the pop-up book festival, Citizen, hope to draw in locals who ldquohavenrsquot been so well represented in the audiences at the August festival.Read more:Citizens Theatre devotes new season solely to female writersCitizen is part of Edinburgh International Book Festival On The Road, a series of events and activities around Scotland throughout the year.It is aimed at ldquogiving a voice to communities in several parts of the city with low levels of involvement in the festivals, including Muirhouse, Wester Hailes and Moredun.People will be encouraged to ldquoexplore their connection to each other and their relationship to their local area as part of the project, starting in .Irvine Welsh, who was born in Leith, moved to Muirhouse when he was four.He attended Ainslie Park High School, nurturing his writing talents and led to the creation of his magnum opus, Trainspotting.Nick Barley, director of the Edinburgh International Book Festival, said: ldquoI feel passionately that book festivals are not just about books."They are much-needed forums for public discourse.ldquoIf we are going to sustain a genuinely inclusive forum for grassroots democratic discussion in Edinburgh, we must reach out more effectively to give everyone the chance to take part."Thatrsquos why itrsquos so exciting to be able to work with community groups that havenrsquot been so well represented in the audiences at the August festival.Read more:Poetry, festivals, artists and bands receive more than pound, in funding from Creative ScotlandIt is being launched after organisers of the book festival staged pop-up events in several locations around Scotland, including Cumbernauld, Irvine, East Kilbride, Livingston and Glenrothes.A team of "community programmers" will be created to help stage the festival at the North Edinburgh Arts centre.They will work alongside centre staff, author Eleanor Thom and the Edinburgh International Book Festival on the venture.Ms Thom said: ldquoThe most powerful stories are likely happening beyond the geography of the festival and exploring these narratives can transform how we all see our city, ourselves and others.ldquoThatrsquos why Citizen is important."Irsquoll be asking what kinds of stories people want to hear, as well as listening to the stories people want to tell."Irsquom motivated by my belief sharing stories can effect change.Citizen is being launched after the book festival received a pound, share of a pound. million initiative.The event is backed by both the Scottish Government and the city council, to spread the benefits of the festivals, which are said to be worth poundm to the economy.Ms Thom will work with writers, musicians, illustrators and other artists to inspire residents to tell their stories of le in Muirhouse and ldquoshare their views on community, home and their relationship to the wider world.North Edinburgh Arts director Kate Wimpress said: ldquoWersquore sure Eleanor, as North Edinburgh Arts writer-in-residence, will spark many interesting conversations and inspire creativity among all the users of our venue and beyond.ldquoWe aim to be a place where we can make connections, share ideas, learn together and take creative risks, and this project will contribute directly to those aims and offer new perspectives for the future.Other offshoots of Citizen will see another Edinburgh-based author, Claire Askew, work with several city high schools.

title: edinburgh-tram-strike-called-off-after-workers-reach-agreement
story: The agreement with Unite "overhauls" the companys sickness and capability policies.:Staff threaten to bring Edinburgh Trams to a standstill over culture of blameThe union held a ballot which overwhelmingly backed the industrial action, in a row over alleged hostile management from Edinburgh Tram bosses.Regional officer Lyn Turner said: "Our members are satisfied that the company has listened to their concerns and has agreed to change practices which will halt strike action."This is the best outcome possible for all those involved."Edinburghs citizens and tourists will be relieved to hear that fruitful talks have led to the withdrawal of strike action.:Lothian Buses in spying controversy over emails sent by staff at Edinburgh Trams"An agreement has been reached through positive consultation and negotiation rather than hard-nosed posturing."Edinburgh Trams must be under no illusion about the strength and resolve of our members who deserve to be treated fairly and with dignity and respect."The strike had been due to take place in the "run-up" to Christmas and last until the end of the year.Almost % of Unite members favoured industrial action, with an % turnout for the ballot.
